data.title: Dateline Resources (ASX:DTR) Is Up 41.4% After Securing US Heavy Rare Earths Exposure
data.description:

  • The deal not only adds heavy rare earths exposure, including minerals such as yttrium and dysprosium, but also links Dateline to broader US uranium and rare earth opportunities through its US$1.0 million equity investment in Fermi Critical Minerals.

The Music Valley Heavy Rare Earths acquisition, alongside the US$1.0 million Fermi Critical Minerals stake, reinforces that story by adding heavy rare earth and uranium exposure on top of Colosseum‚Äôs gold and rare earth potential. data.title: Deere (DE) Margin Compression In Q1 2026 Tests Premium P/E Growth Narrative
data.description:
Deere (DE) opened fiscal 2026 with Q1 revenue of US$9.6b and basic EPS of US$2.43, setting the tone for how its equipment demand and pricing are feeding through to the bottom line. Over the last few quarters, the company has seen quarterly revenue move from US$10.96b in Q4 2024 to between US$8.5b and US$12.8b through 2025, while basic EPS ranged from US$3.20 to US$6.65 in that period. This gives investors a clear view of how earnings have tracked alongside the top line. With trailing 12 month margins at 10.3% versus 13% in the prior year, this latest print puts the focus squarely on how efficiently Deere is turning revenue into profit.

See our full analysis for Deere.

With the headline numbers on the table, the next step is to see how Deere‚Äôs recent results line up with the key stories investors follow about its growth, profitability and risks.

See what the community is saying about Deere

Advertisement

TTM earnings slip to US$4.8b while revenue holds at US$46.7b

  • Over the last 12 months, Deere generated about US$46.7b in revenue and US$4.8b in net income, compared with US$51.5b revenue and US$7.1b net income in the prior 12 month snapshot, highlighting that profit has softened more than sales.
  • Consensus narrative points to precision agriculture tech and automation as future earnings drivers, yet the recent margin picture shows some friction:
    • Net profit margin over the last year is 10.3%, down from 13%, even as analysts expect earnings to grow about 15.8% a year.
    • That contrast supports the idea that higher margin software and automation could help over time, but it also shows that optimistic views are leaning on forecasts while recent profitability has moved the other way.

Consistent revenue but softer earnings often get optimistic and skeptical investors looking at different parts of the story, so it is worth seeing how Deere‚Äôs tech push and margin trends line up in the detailed narratives: üìä Read the what the Community is saying about Deere.

Premium 35.3x P/E meets DCF fair value of US$687.87

  • Deere trades on a trailing P/E of 35.3x versus peer and US Machinery industry averages of 27.5x and 28.4x, while its current share price of US$629.71 sits below the DCF fair value estimate of US$687.87 and the analyst price target of US$665.33.
  • Some investors argue that paying up for Deere is justified by expected earnings growth, but the numbers cut both ways:
    • Forecast earnings growth of about 15.8% a year is slightly higher than the US market‚Äôs 15.6%, which supports the idea of a quality growth profile.
    • At the same time, paying a premium P/E while net margins have moved from 13% to 10.3% means the optimistic stance leans heavily on those growth and margin expansion forecasts playing out.

If you are trying to figure out whether that premium multiple fits the optimistic case, it can help to see how bullish investors are framing Deere‚Äôs long term story and where they think earnings can go from here: üêÇ Deere Bull Case

Cash flow coverage of debt flagged as key risk

  • One of the clearest red flags in the recent analysis is that debt is not well covered by operating cash flow over the last 12 months, even though net income over that period was US$4.8b and margins were 10.3%.
  • More cautious investors highlight that heavy reliance on financing and incentives could strain Deere if conditions stay tough, and this cash flow data gives that view some support:
    • The major risk called out is specifically weak cash coverage of debt, not just lower earnings, which ties directly to how resilient the balance sheet is during slower patches.
    • With revenue growth over the last year at 2.3%, below the broader US market‚Äôs 10.3%, skeptics focus on whether modest top line expansion plus softer margins leaves less flexibility to strengthen cash generation relative to debt.

For anyone weighing that more cautious angle, it can be useful to see how bears connect these cash flow and margin pressures to longer term downside scenarios: üêª Deere Bear Case

After weighing both the upbeat and cautious threads in this story, it may be helpful to review the details promptly and check the numbers yourself, starting with 2 key rewards and 1 important warning sign.

data.title: A Look At Empire State Realty OP (ESBA) Valuation After Prolonged Weak Share Performance
data.description:
Advertisement

Empire State Realty OP overview

Empire State Realty OP (ESBA) has recently attracted attention after a stretch of weak share performance, with negative returns over the past month, past 3 months, year to date, and the past year.

The partnership, which operates as a subsidiary of Empire State Realty Trust, sits at a recent closing price of US$6.05 and is currently flagged with an intrinsic discount of about 69% based on available estimates.

See our latest analysis for Empire State Realty OP.

Short term trading has been choppy, with a 7 day share price return of 1.85% set against a 30 day share price return decline of 7.77%. The 1 year total shareholder return decline of 33.33% suggests momentum has been fading over a longer stretch despite the current discount estimate.

If Empire State Realty OP‚Äôs recent moves have you reassessing your options, it could be a good moment to see what else stands out in our 19 top founder-led companies.

With ESBA trading at US$6.05 and tagged with an estimated 69% intrinsic discount after years of negative total returns, you have to ask: is this a genuine value gap, or is the market already pricing in its future growth?

Price-to-Earnings of 30.4x: Is it justified?

Empire State Realty OP is currently on a P/E of 30.4x, and that sits against a last close of $6.05 and an internal fair value estimate suggesting the units trade at a 68.9% discount.

The P/E ratio simply compares the current unit price to earnings per unit. At 30.4x you are paying about 30 times the latest earnings for each $1 of ESBA‚Äôs profit. For a REIT style business, a higher P/E can reflect expectations around earnings stability, income potential, or future cash flows, but it can also sit uncomfortably beside weaker near term profit trends.

Here, there are a few tensions for you to weigh. On one side, ESBA is flagged as trading at 68.9% below an estimated fair value of $19.44 using the SWS DCF model, and the partnership moved from loss making to profitable over the past 5 years, with earnings growing 47.6% per year over that period. On the other side, Return on Equity is low at 3.3%, net profit margin has softened from 9.7% to 7.2%, earnings contracted by 24.3% over the last year, interest payments are not well covered by earnings, and the last 12 months include a $14.4m one off gain that clouds the quality of earnings.

Relative to peers, the story is mixed too. The current 30.4x P/E is described as expensive against the Global REITs industry average of 16.1x, which suggests the market is pricing ESBA higher than many REITs in aggregate. At the same time, the units are described as good value against a peer group average P/E of 44x, which implies that within a closer set of comparable companies, ESBA trades on a lower earnings multiple than others in that peer set.

See what the numbers say about this price ‚Äî find out in our valuation breakdown.

Result: Price-to-Earnings of 30.4x (ABOUT RIGHT)

However, you still need to weigh softer margins and a low 3.3% Return on Equity, which could limit earnings quality and challenge that apparent 69% discount.

Another view on ESBA‚Äôs value

The P/E of 30.4x suggests ESBA trades richer than the Global REITs industry at 16.1x, yet cheaper than its peer group average of 44x. The key question is whether the risk lies in sentiment moving closer to the broader sector‚Äôs lower multiple, or in peers influencing ESBA‚Äôs rating toward a higher level over time.

data.description:

  • Over shorter periods the stock has been volatile, with a 6.7% decline over the last week and a 7.5% decline over the last month, although the 1 year return of 41.9% and a very large 3 year return indicate a very strong run over a longer horizon.

At the same time, commentary about AI related spending by major cloud providers and enterprise customers has kept expectations for NVIDIA firmly in the spotlight.

Approach 1: NVIDIA Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model takes estimates of a company‚Äôs future cash flows and discounts them back to today to arrive at an estimate of what the business might be worth per share right now.

For NVIDIA, the model uses a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach based on cash flow projections in $. The latest twelve month free cash flow is about $97.2b. Analysts provide free cash flow estimates for several years ahead, and beyond that Simply Wall St extrapolates the path, with projected free cash flow reaching $325.1b in 2031 and continuing with further estimates out to 2035.

After discounting these projected cash flows back to today, the model arrives at an estimated intrinsic value of $161.88 per share. Compared with the current share price, this implies the stock is about 9.5% overvalued, which is a relatively small gap and suggests expectations and the cash flow outlook are broadly aligned.

Result: ABOUT RIGHT

NVIDIA is fairly valued according to our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF), but this can change at a moment's notice. Track the value in your watchlist or portfolio and be alerted on when to act.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for NVIDIA.

Approach 2: NVIDIA Price vs Earnings (P/E)

For a profitable company like NVIDIA, the P/E ratio is a useful way to see what investors are paying for each dollar of current earnings. It helps you compare the share price with the company‚Äôs profit today, without getting too deep into complex models.

In general, higher growth expectations and lower perceived risk can support a higher P/E, while slower expected growth or higher risk usually point to a lower, more conservative P/E range.

NVIDIA currently trades on a P/E of 35.86x. That sits below the Semiconductor industry average of 43.84x and well below the peer average of 87.49x, which indicates the stock is priced more cautiously than many direct peers.

Simply Wall St‚Äôs Fair Ratio for NVIDIA is 54.79x. This is a proprietary estimate of what P/E might be appropriate given factors such as earnings growth, profit margins, industry, market cap and risk profile. Because it weighs these company specific drivers, the Fair Ratio can be more informative than a simple comparison with broad industry or peer averages.

Comparing the current P/E of 35.86x with the Fair Ratio of 54.79x suggests the shares trade below that fair range.

data.title: Carter‚Äôs (CRI) Margin Compression To 3.2% Reinforces Bearish Profitability Narratives
data.description:
Carter's (CRI) has wrapped up FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of US$925.5 million and basic EPS of US$1.76, alongside net income of US$64.2 million. This puts a clear spotlight on how effectively it is turning sales into profit. The company has seen quarterly revenue move from US$859.7 million and EPS of US$1.71 in Q4 2024 to US$925.5 million and EPS of US$1.76 in Q4 2025. Trailing twelve month revenue of US$2.9 billion and EPS of US$2.53 set the broader earnings backdrop. For investors, the latest results put the focus squarely on how sustainable these margins look as the business moves through the next phase of its cycle.

See our full analysis for Carter's.

With the headline numbers on the table, the next step is to see how this earnings print lines up against the widely held narratives about Carter's growth, risks, and profitability story.

See what the community is saying about Carter's

Advertisement

Margins Under Pressure At 3.2%

  • On a trailing basis, Carter's net profit margin sits at 3.2%, compared with 6.3% a year earlier, and trailing twelve month net income is US$91.8 million on US$2.9b of revenue.
  • Bears argue that margin pressure will stick because tariffs and cost inflation are lifting the effective duty rate into the high 30% range and Carter's is leaning on broad price increases to offset this, which they see as risky for a price sensitive young family customer base.
    • This concern lines up with the drop in trailing margin from 6.3% to 3.2%, as higher duties and input costs can compress earnings even when revenue, at about US$2.9b, remains relatively stable over the last twelve months.
    • Critics also point to the plan to close about 150 North American stores and reduce office based roles by roughly 15% as a sign the current store fleet and cost base are under pressure, and they question whether planned US$45 million of savings will be enough to offset those headwinds and support higher profitability.
Over the last year, Carter's has seen EPS across 2025 quarters swing from US$0.01 in Q2 to US$1.76 in Q4, and bears are watching whether future cost savings truly reverse the visible squeeze in margins or simply keep earnings roughly in line with recent levels. üêª Carter's Bear Case

Revenue Growth Slow, Earnings Forecasts Higher

  • Forecasts point to revenue growing around 1.1% per year while earnings are expected to grow about 9.7% per year, compared with five year earnings that have declined roughly 15% per year.
  • Supporters of the bullish view think this gap between modest revenue growth and faster earnings growth can hold, because they see several levers working in Carter's favor, including digital channel expansion, store rationalization and product simplification.
    • They highlight plans to reposition Carter's, OshKosh, Little Planet and Otter Avenue as primary brands on Amazon and other wholesale platforms, which they believe can lift higher value assortments and support Wholesale segment earnings even if total company revenue climbs only a little above the current US$2.9b level.
    • Bulls also point to the planned US$45 million in annual productivity savings and the reduction of 20% to 30% of product choices, arguing that better inventory quality and a more efficient cost base can help translate low single digit revenue growth into the 9.7% earnings growth that is currently projected.
If you are trying to weigh this slow top line outlook against the earnings growth forecasts, it can help to see how bullish analysts connect Carter's cost actions and channel mix to their longer term story. üêÇ Carter's Bull Case

P/E Of 13.3x Versus DCF Value

  • Carter's trades on a P/E of 13.3x compared with peers at 27.8x and the US Luxury industry at 21x, while a DCF fair value of US$13.94 sits well below the current share price of US$33.39.
  • Consensus style analysis suggests this mix of low relative P/E and a DCF fair value below the market price gives investors two very different signals to weigh, especially when set alongside the long run earnings record.
    • On one hand, the 13.3x P/E is lower than both peers and the broader US market at 19.6x, which is consistent with the idea that the stock appears inexpensive compared with similar companies even though trailing twelve month EPS is US$2.53 on net income of US$91.8 million.
    • On the other hand, the DCF fair value of US$13.94 and the roughly 15% per year five year earnings decline highlight that, despite the lower P/E, longer term profit trends and cash flow estimates have been weaker, which is why some analysts are more cautious about how much upside is left from here.

Next Steps

To see how these results tie into long-term growth, risks, and valuation, check out the full range of community narratives for Carter's on Simply Wall St. Add the company to your watchlist or portfolio so you'll be alerted when the story evolves.

Mixed messages in the numbers so far? If you want to move quickly and build your own view, start by weighing the company's 3 key rewards and 2 important warning signs.

See What Else Is Out There

data.title: Is It Time To Reassess THOR Industries (THO) After Recent Share Price Weakness
data.description:

  • The stock closed at US$96.13, with returns of a 15.4% decline over 7 days, a 14.1% decline over 30 days and an 8.8% decline year to date. The 1 year return sits at a 1.1% decline and the 3 year return at 11.1%.

Advertisement

Approach 1: THOR Industries Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow model estimates what a business could be worth by projecting its future cash flows and then discounting those back to today‚Äôs value using a required return. It is essentially asking what THOR Industries‚Äô future cash generation is worth in today‚Äôs dollars.

For THOR Industries, the model uses a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach, starting from last twelve months free cash flow of about US$356.2 million. Analyst and extrapolated projections then step this forward, with free cash flow estimates such as US$272.1 million in 2026 and US$609.9 million in 2035, all in US$. Simply Wall St only takes direct analyst inputs for the earlier years, with later years extrapolated to build a full 10 year path.

Discounting this stream of projected cash flows back to today results in an estimated intrinsic value of about US$108.19 per share. Compared with the recent share price of US$96.13, the model implies the stock is 11.1% undervalued on this basis.

Result: UNDERVALUED

Approach 2: THOR Industries Price vs Earnings

For a profitable company like THOR Industries, the P/E ratio is a useful shorthand for what investors are currently paying for each dollar of earnings. It rolls expectations about future growth and perceived risk into a single number, since higher growth or lower risk often line up with a higher ‚Äúnormal‚Äù P/E, while lower growth or higher risk tend to justify a lower one.

THOR Industries is trading on a P/E of 18.01x. That sits close to the Auto industry average P/E of 18.98x, and below the peer group average of 21.45x. To go a step further, Simply Wall St calculates a proprietary ‚ÄúFair Ratio‚Äù of 18.65x for THOR Industries. This figure reflects factors such as the company‚Äôs earnings profile, profit margin, industry, market cap and risk characteristics, rather than just a simple comparison with peers.

Because the Fair Ratio is tailored to the company, it can be more informative than looking at raw industry or peer multiples alone. With the current P/E of 18.01x versus a Fair Ratio of 18.65x, THOR Industries appears modestly undervalued on this metric.
